intro: Hordeum vulgare var. distichon, commonly known as two-row barley, is a variant of barley characterized by its two-row arrangement of grains on the spike. It is a grass species native to Europe and western Asia, and it has been cultivated for thousands of years. The plant typically grows to a height of 1 to 2 meters, with narrow, grass-like leaves and a cylindrical spike bearing small, two-rowed grains. It thrives in temperate climates and is well-suited for agricultural cultivation due to its adaptability and high yield potential. The botanical features of this variety make it an important crop for both food and industrial uses.
